content.text: Once upon a time, in a land far away, there lived a beautiful princess who loved to play in the woods near her father’s castle.
One sunny afternoon, she wandered deeper into the forest than she had ever gone before, until she came to a clear, sparkling pond. The water was so inviting that she sat down on a mossy stone by
the edge and began to play with her favorite toy—a golden ball that gleamed in the sunlight. As she tossed the ball into the air and caught it, she laughed with delight.
But on one throw, the ball slipped from her fingers and rolled away, bouncing down the bank and plopping into the pond with a soft *splash*.
The princess gasped and leaned over the water, but the ball had sunk too deep for her to reach. She tried to stretch her arms as far as they would go, but it was no use. The golden ball was lost.
Tears welled up in her eyes, and she began to cry. "Oh, my beautiful ball!" she sobbed. "How will I ever get it back?" Just then, a deep, croaky voice spoke from the water.
"Why are you crying, princess?" Startled, the princess looked down and saw a large, green frog sitting on a lily pad. His bulging eyes blinked at her, and his wide mouth turned up in what might have

been a smile. "I—I’ve lost my golden ball," she said between sniffles. "It fell into the pond, and I can’t reach it." The frog tilted his head. "I could fetch it for you," he said, "but what will you give me in
return?" The princess wiped her tears and thought for a moment. "I’ll give you my pearls, my jewels, even my golden crown!" she exclaimed. The frog shook his head. "I do not care for such things.
But if you will love me and let me be your companion—if you will let me eat from your golden plate and sleep upon your pillow—then I will dive into the water and bring back your ball."
The princess hesitated. A frog? As her companion? The idea seemed ridiculous. But she wanted her ball so badly that she nodded quickly. "Yes, yes! I promise! Just bring me my ball!"
The frog dove into the water with a little *plop* and disappeared beneath the surface. The princess waited, her heart pounding with hope.
After a few moments, the frog surfaced, holding the golden ball in his mouth. He swam to the edge of the pond and dropped it onto the bank. The princess clapped her hands with joy.
"Oh, thank you, thank you!" she cried, snatching up the ball. Without another word, she turned and ran back toward the castle as fast as her legs would carry her, leaving the frog behind. "Wait!"

the frog called after her. "Take me with you, as you promised!" But the princess did not stop. She ran all the way home, her golden ball clutched tightly in her hand, and forgot all about the frog and
her promise. That evening, as the princess sat at the royal table for supper, there came a loud *knock-knock-knock* at the castle door.
A servant opened it, and there stood the frog, dripping wet and looking very determined. "Let me in!" he croaked. "I have come to claim what the princess promised me."
The servant hurried to the dining hall and told the king what had happened. The king, who was wise and fair, called his daughter to him. "Daughter," he said sternly, "you made a promise to this frog.
A promise must always be kept, no matter how small or strange it may seem. Go and let him in." With a sigh, the princess went to the door and opened it.
The frog hopped inside, his webbed feet making little *squelching* sounds on the marble floor. "Now," said the frog, "take me to your room and let me sleep upon your pillow."

The princess wrinkled her nose. "Must I?" she asked. "Yes," said the king firmly. "A promise is a promise." So the princess picked up the frog—though she held him as far from her as possible—and carried
him up the grand staircase to her chamber. She set him down on her silken pillow, but as soon as she turned away, the frog hopped after her. "Now," he said, "let me eat from your golden plate."
The princess groaned but did as she was told. She placed a tiny bit of food on her golden plate and set it before the frog. To her surprise, he ate it with great relish, licking his lips afterward.
When supper was over, the frog hopped onto the princess’s bed and settled himself on her pillow. The princess shuddered but climbed into bed, pulling the covers up to her chin.
She tried to ignore the frog, but he kept croaking softly, as if he were trying to say something. Finally, the princess could bear it no longer. "Oh, very well!" she snapped. "What do you want now?"
The frog looked at her with his big, round eyes. "Kiss me," he said. The princess gasped. "Kiss you? A frog? Never!" But the frog was insistent.
"You promised to love me and let me be your companion. If you truly meant your promise, then you must kiss me." The princess hesitated. She did not want to kiss a frog, but she also did not want to
break her word. With a deep breath, she leaned forward and pressed a quick, reluctant kiss upon the frog’s damp, bumpy head.
The moment her lips touched him, there was a bright flash of light, and a great *POP!* echoed through the room. The princess blinked in surprise—and then she gasped.
Where the frog had been, there now stood a handsome young prince, dressed in fine clothes, with a kind smile upon his face. "Oh!" cried the princess. "Who are you?" The prince bowed deeply.
"I am the prince whom you have freed from a wicked enchantment. A cruel witch turned me into a frog, and only the kiss of a true princess could break the spell.
You, dear princess, have set me free." The princess clapped her hands in delight. "Then you are no longer a frog?" "No," said the prince, laughing. "And I am forever in your debt."
The king, who had heard the commotion, came rushing into the room. When he saw the prince, he was overjoyed. "This is wonderful!" he exclaimed. "A prince in our castle!"
The prince explained everything to the king, and the two of them agreed that the princess had done a very brave and kind thing.
The next day, the prince asked the princess if she would marry him, and she, who had grown quite fond of him, said yes. A grand wedding was held in the castle, and all the people from the

kingdom came to celebrate. The princess and the prince lived happily ever after, and if you listen very carefully on a quiet night, you might still hear the sound of their laughter echoing through the
forest. And as for the golden ball? It was placed in the royal treasury, where it shone even brighter than before, a reminder of the day a princess kept her promise—and found true love in the most
unexpected of places.
